awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Bacterial spatial organization as a microscale mechanism of ecosystem resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Ecosystems — from plant roots to animal guts to oceans — are sustained by their microbial communities: collections of microorganisms that can protect or promote disease, depending on the environmental conditions. These communities routinely experience and endure environmental change. Some environmental changes destabilize communities, leading to pronounced changes in the microbial species composing a community. How these changes persist, even long after normal environmental conditions return, is not yet understood. This project seeks to learn how the spatial organization of single bacterial cells can determine how the bacterial community within the mammalian gut responds to environmental perturbation. By combining sequence-based observation with biophysical insights, the Fellow seeks to provide the first causal mechanism to explain and visualize how some gut ecosystems recover from disturbance while others suffer lasting change. Students recruited from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines will engage in these activities with the Fellow. 

This project will investigate how organization of intestinal communities maintains the homeostasis of their host’s gut ecosystem by changing the bacterial species residing in microscopic folds of the gut epithelium (crypts). Both crypt- and whole-gut species composition can be altered after diarrhea, a perturbation that increases the abundance of some bacterial species and causes the extinction of others. Diarrhea also alters mucus and fluid flow in the gut that might enable changes in bacterial spatial organization that favor or destabilize the presence of specific species in the gut. To test this, the Fellow will develop a microfluidic system to track bacterial movement in a structural mimic of the mucus and fluid flow in the gut. The Fellow will generate a spatio-temporal map of bacteria in pre- and post-diarrhea guts to link in situ spatial organization with whole community composition. These multiscale data will unveil bacterial behaviors currently masked by prevailing sequencing techniques. This dataset, and all tools developed to generate it, will be made available through public repositories to promote multiscale research across diverse ecosystems. The training objectives include developing new skills in bioinformatics and histology, enabling the Fellow to complement findings from these methods with existing expertise in microfluidics and bacterial growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microbes are vital to healthy ecosystems. They produce half the oxygen we breathe. They create the nutrients needed for veggies to grow. They turn the veggies we eat into products that actually nourish human cells. Be it an ocean, the soil, or the human gut, the microbial communities in an ecosystem determine the ecosystem?s health and function.

 

As vital as they are, we cannot yet predict whether a microbial ecosystem will recover from disturbance or suffer lasting change. This project sought to determine sources of gut ecosystem resilience to a major intestinal disturbance: diarrhea. Achieving such would provide the field with a framework to understand diverse microbial systems and help advance microbial ecology into a predictive science, capable of forecasting ecosystem responses to diverse disturbance. 

 

 

Towards this goal, this project has contributed findings that improve our understanding of how gut bacteria respond to environmental disturbance. Specifically, outcomes of this project answer the following questions:

 

  1. How can changes in acidity impact the growth of bacteria in the human gut?

  2. How can changes in osmotic pressure impact the growth of bacteria in the human gut?

  3. Do changes in the environment (like acidity and osmotic pressure) affect microbial communities at the community-level or at the level of individual species?

 

Certain foods, medications, and health conditions can change gut acidity (pH) and osmolality. By measuring how changes in pH and osmotic pressure alter the growth rate of 92 different species of gut bacteria, we now know which bacterial species are most affected by these changes and which are more resilient. These results are published and can now be used to ask: are the most resilient ecosystems those that contain more resilient species of bacteria? The article is publicly available at https://doi.org/10.1128/mbio.00753-23.

 

The third question takes a step back from a species-focused approach and considers the possibility that ecosystem resilience may be more dependent on the interactions between bacterial species, instead of the presence of specific species themselves. By studying whether environmental disturbances affect microbial communities at the community-level or the species-level, we ask: what features within an ecosystem should be observed to understand its resilience? Our study found that interactions are indeed important, and these results are now under peer review for publication.

 

 

In addition to advancing scientific understanding, the project also sought to promote public knowledge of current topics in microbiology. This project developed outreach materials, written and illustrated for a general audience, to share what is known about how gut bacteria respond to human diets and affect human health. This content is openly available online at https://jkimthu.com/food-us-and-bugs/. 


This project also developed educational material to facilitate discussions between researchers on responsible research practices. This material identifies two articles describing how scientific trends can impact public health and how categorizing certain human traits as scientific variables can perpetuate systemic racism. The material also suggests reading questions to initiate reflection and discussion and is openly available at https://jkimthu.github.io/teaching/MICB430_dec1.pdf.

Modified by: Jen Nguyen
